author: Jonathan Walker
title: Brexit MP backs for Theresa May plan for leaving the European Union
text:
Brexit MP backs for Theresa May plan for leaving the European Union 16:29, 24 Oct 2016 By Jonathan Walker High-profile Brexit MP Anne-Marie Trevelyan supports Theresa May's proposal to enshrine EU rules in British law Share Get daily news by email Prime Minister Theresa May 
Theresa May ’s controversial Brexit plans were backed by a high-profile “leave” campaigner. 
Anne-Marie Trevelyan, Conservative MP Berwick-upon-Tweed, endorsed the Prime Minister’s proposal to incorporate all EU law into UK law - so it continues to be enforced even after we leave the European Union. 
It follows reports that the Prime Minister faces a rebellion from some Tory backbenchers led by Grant Shapps, the former Conservative chairman. 
The Times reported that they would attempt to defeat the Government in the House of Commons when it introduces the “Great Repeal Bill”, which will end the supremacy of EU law in the UK. 
Mrs May announced during the Conservative Party conference in early October that the Bill will annul the 1972 European Communities Act (ECA). But it will also incorporate all existing EU law into UK law. 
And Brexit-supporting MPs are reportedly planning to attach a “sunset clause” under which the EU-made laws within the bill would stop being in force after five years. 
But Mrs Trevelyan said she backed the Prime Minister’s approach. 
She said: “I think it’s a very sensible way to move forward as part of the Brexit programme. 
“For me, the repeal of the 1972 Act is the critical starting point. 
“In so doing, you have to make sure that in the short term you don’t leave any legal gaps. So bringing in all EU law into EU law is the way to ensure that. 
“And then we can, in a measured state of calm over several years and in negotiations with all those who are affected by them, remove any which are no longer required for a free and independent Great Britain.” 
Mrs May has offered to involve Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland in regular formal talks on the Brexit process in an effort to quell concern about her handling of the situation. 
Downing Street said Mrs May will tell the leaders of the devolved administrations concerned about a possible hard Brexit that final decisions about her approach had not yet been taken and “how the UK leaves the EU will not boil down to a binary choice”. 
Mrs May will come under pressure from Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, Welsh counterpart Carwyn Jones and Northern Ireland’s leader Arlene Foster and her deputy Martin McGuinness at a meeting in Downing Street. Conservative MP for Berwick Anne-Marie Trevelyan 
The devolved administrations are keen to secure continued participation in the single market and want to hold votes on Mrs May’s approach before she triggers Article 50, formally beginning the Brexit process. 
The Prime Minister has offered them a “direct line” to Brexit Secretary David Davis, who will chair a new forum bringing together representatives from Westminster, Holyrood, Cardiff Bay and Stormont for regular talks on the situation. 
But there is no sign of a voice for the English regions, despite demands that the needs of the North East must be considered in talks. 
Think tank IPPR North has said the region needs what it called a Northern Brexit Negotiating Committee, including the North’s leading politicians, top business people, exporters, importers and innovators, and key public service leaders. to advise the government on Brexit. 
And Paul Watson, chair of the North East Combined Authority and leader of Sunderland City Council, said earlier this year that the north of England had as much right to be consulted as Scotland. 
He was one of a number of northern leaders to write to Mrs May demanding a place at the Brexit negotiating table. Read More Marmite and ice cream - how Brexit is already changing our lives 
Chairs or leaders of the Greater Manchester Combined Authority, Liverpool City Region Combined Authority, Sheffield City Region Combined Authority and West Yorkshire Combined Authority also signed the letter inviting Mrs May “to meet with us at your earliest convenience to discuss our role within the Brexit negotiations and how we can work together for the benefit of the North.” 
Announcing plans to involve Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, the Prime Minister said: “I am determined that as we make a success of our exit from the European Union, we in turn further strengthen our own enduring union.” 
She added: “The new forum I am offering will be the chance for them all to put forward their proposals on how to seize the opportunities presented by Brexit and deliver the democratic decision expressed by the people of the UK.”
